sen.j: 明石 覚一（あかし かくいち、正安元年（1299年） - 応安4年（1371年））は、南北朝時代 (日本)の平家琵琶（一方流）演奏家である。
sen.e: Kakuichi AKASHI (1299-1371) was a Heike biwa (biwa with four strings and five frets used to play Heike Monogatari) performing musician (Ichikata school) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Kakuichi AKASHI (1299-1371) was a Heike biwa (biwa with four strings and five frets used to play Heike Monogatari) musician (Ichikata school) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Kakuichi AKASHI (1299-1371) was a Heike biwa (biwa with four strings and five frets used to play Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike)) musician (Ichikata school) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

sen.j: 足利尊氏の従弟で明石を領した。
sen.e: He was an apprentice of Takauji ASHIKAGA and governed Akashi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was an apprentice of Takauji ASHIKAGA and governed Akashi.
He was an apprentice of Takauji ASHIKAGA and governed Akashi.

sen.j: 中年まで播州（兵庫県）書写山の僧であったが、急に失明し琵琶法師となった。
sen.e: He was a monk of the Shosha-zan Mountain in Banshu, which is an old name for part of Hyogo prefecture, until he reached his middle age, but suddenly lost his eyesight, and became a biwa-playing minstrel.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was a monk of Shosha-zan Mountain in Banshu, which is an old name for part of Hyogo prefecture, until he reached his middle age, but suddenly lost his eyesight, and became a biwa-playing minstrel.
He was a monk of Shosha-zan Mountain in Banshu, which is an old name for part of Hyogo prefecture, until he reached his middle age, but suddenly lost his eyesight, and became a biwa-playing minstrel.

sen.j: 彼は自分の屋敷に当道座を設立して、みずから惣検校となり、明石検校とも言われている。
sen.e: He opened Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) at his residence, and became a chairman of the highest-rank officials of the guild for the blind to be called Kengyo AKASHI (another name of Kakuichi AKASHI).

He opened Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) at his residence, and became a chairman of the highest-rank officials of the guild for the blind, to be called Kengyo AKASHI (another name of Kakuichi AKASHI).

He opened Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind) at his residence, and became so-kengyo (the chairman of the highest-rank officials of the guild for the blind), to be called Akashi Kengyo (another name of Kakuichi AKASHI).
sen.cmt: so-kengyo 追記し、説明を括弧書きにしました。（名前のKengyo の由来を示すため。）Kengyo AKASHI→Akashi Kengyo

sen.j: 江戸時代まで続く検校制度を確立した。
sen.e: He established a kengyo system, which persisted into the Edo period.
He established a kengyo system, which persisted into the Edo period.
He established a kengyo system, which persisted into the Edo period.

sen.j: 当道座は現在洛央小学校となっている。
sen.e: Todo-za is now Rakuo Elementary School.
Todo-za is now Rakuo Elementary School.
Todo-za is now Rakuo Elementary School.

sen.j: 彼は琵琶の名手で、耳なし芳一のモデルと言われている。
sen.e: He was an expert biwa (Japanese player) player, and is considered a model of earless Hoichi.
He was an expert biwa (Japanese lute) player, and is considered a model of earless Hoichi.
He was an expert biwa (Japanese lute) player, and is considered a model of earless Hoichi.

sen.j: 一方（いちかた）流の流祖如一の弟子、一方流中興の祖と呼ばれる。
sen.e: He is called an apprentice of the founder of the Ichikata school, and Chuko no So (father of restoration) of the Ichikata school.
He is called an apprentice of the founder of the Ichikata school, and Chuko no So (father of restoration) of the Ichikata school.
He is called an apprentice of the founder of the Ichikata school, and Chuko no So (father of restoration) of the Ichikata school.

sen.j: 天皇・上皇・親王らのための御前演奏をおこなうことが多かった。
sen.e: He often performed in front of the Imperial family, including an emperor, retired emperors, and imperial princes and princesses.
He often performed in front of the Imperial family, including an emperor, retired emperors, and imperial princes and princesses.
He often performed in front of the Imperial family, including an emperor, retired emperors, and imperial princes and princesses.

sen.j: 琵琶以外にも按摩（あんま）・鍼灸（しんきゅう）の達人でもあったと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said that he was an expert not only in performing biwa but also in massage and acupuncture.
It is said that he was an expert not only in playing biwa but also in massage and acupuncture.
It is said that he was an expert not only in playing biwa but also in massage and acupuncture.

sen.j: 覚一は、当時貴族や武士の間に平曲を弾じて、その至芸を称された。
sen.e: Kakuichi performed Heikyoku (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) and praised by nobles and samurai in those days for his unrivaled performance.
Kakuichi performed Heikyoku (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) and was praised by nobles and samurai in those days for his unrivaled performance.
Kakuichi performed Heikyoku (the music played on Heike biwa as accompaniment for the recitation of Heike monogatari) and was praised by nobles and samurai in those days for his unrivaled performance.

sen.j: 貞治2年（1362年）にも、覚一が勧進勧進平家を演じた記録が、中原師守の日記である『師守記』の同年正月3日の条に見える。
sen.e: A record of Kakuichi's performance of Kanjin Heike in 1362 is found in the chapter on the third day of the New Year in "Moromori-ki," which is a diary of Moromori NAKAHARA.
sen.cmt: 勧進勧進平家：勧進平家と解釈して訳しております。
sen.e: A record of Kakuichi's performance of Kanjin Heike in 1362 is found in the chapter on the third day of the New Year in "Moromori-ki," which is a diary of Moromori NAKAHARA.

A record of Kakuichi's performance of Kanjin Heike (play for collecting money for repairing or constructing temples) in 1362 is found in the chapter on the 26th day of the New Year in "Moromori-ki," which is a diary of Moromori NAKAHARA.
sen.cmt: 勧進平家の定訳不明ですが、説明補足しました。旧暦→グレゴリオ暦

sen.j: 今日家君密々聴聞五条高倉薬師堂覚一検校平給
sen.e: 今日家君密々聴聞五条高倉薬師堂覚一検校平給
今日家君密々聴聞五条高倉薬師堂覚一検校平給

sen.cmt: 意味解釈が困難なため訳出せず英語のままにしました。

sen.j: なお、「五条高倉薬師堂」とは、狂言「因幡堂」で知られる京都市下京区の平等寺 (京都市下京区)のことである。
sen.e: "Yakushi-do Hall at gojo-takakura" is Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), which is known for kyogen "Inabado."
sen.cmt: 五条高倉薬師堂：定訳不明のため仮訳です。
sen.e: "Yakushi-do Hall at gojo-takakura" is Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), which is known for kyogen "Inabado."
Yakushi-do Hall at gojo-takakura is Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City), which is known for kyogen 'Inabado.'
sen.cmt: 文頭の" 削除し、他は" "→' '

sen.j: 南北朝時代から室町時代にかけて、平曲をさかんにした功績は大きい。
sen.e: He made a remarkable achievement in making Heikyoku popular during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Muromachi period.
He made a remarkable achievement in making Heikyoku popular during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Muromachi period.
He made a remarkable achievement in making Heikyoku popular during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Muromachi period.

sen.j: また、のちの『平家物語』のスタンダードとも言うべき「覚一本」をまとめた。
sen.e: He edited "Kakuichi-bon Text," which later became standard "The Tale of the Heike."
He edited "Kakuichi-bon Text," which later became the standard "The Tale of the Heike."
He edited 'Kakuichi-bon Text,' which later became the standard "The Tale of the Heike."

sen.j: 以前よりその傾向はあったが、「灌頂巻」が『平家物語』より分立したことは、覚一によって決定的なものとなった。
sen.e: There had been a trend toward separation of "Kanjo no maki" (the Initiate's Chapter) from "The Tale of the Heike," but it was finally separated by Kakuichi.
There had been a trend toward separation of "Kanjo no maki" (the Initiate's Chapter) from "The Tale of the Heike," but it was finally separated by Kakuichi.
There had been a trend toward separation of 'Kanjo no maki' (the Initiate's Chapter) from "The Tale of the Heike," but it was finally separated by Kakuichi.

sen.j: 「灌頂巻」とは、壇ノ浦の戦いで海に身を投げながら助けられ、出家した平徳子による念仏三昧の日々や侍女の悲恋話の部分である。
sen.e: "Kanjo no maki" is a chapter describing days of nenbutsu-zammai (mental absorption in he nenbutsu) of TAIRA no Tokuko, who jumped into the sea in te naval battle of Danno-ura but rescued and entered into priesthood, and a tragic love story of a maid.

"Kanjo no maki" is a chapter describing days of nenbutsu-zammai (mental absorption in the nenbutsu) of TAIRA no Tokuko, who jumped into the sea in the naval battle of Danno-ura but was rescued and entered the priesthood, and a tragic love story of a maid.

Kanjo no maki is a chapter describing days of nenbutsu-zanmai (mental absorption in the nenbutsu) of TAIRA no Tokuko, who jumped into the sea in the naval battle of Danno-ura but was rescued and entered the priesthood, and a tragic love story of a maid.

sen.j: こんにちの『平家物語』の伝本百数十本のうち、平家物語語り本系としての「覚一本」系統の諸本は、重大な位置を占めており、そのなかでも高野辰之旧蔵の高野本（現在東京大学国語研究室所蔵）をもとにしたものが最も流布している。
sen.e: Among one hundred and several tens of denpon (existent books of transcription and published books) of "The Tale of the Heike," transcription and published books of the "Kakuichi-bon Text" line as narration books for "The Tale of the Heike" assume an important role, and especially those based on Takano bon (Takano book) formally owned by Tatsuyuki TAKANO and currently by the Laboratory of Japanese, the University of Tokyo have been popularly distributed.

Among one hundred and several tens of denpon (existent books of transcription and published books) of "The Tale of the Heike," transcription and published books of the "Kakuichi-bon Text" line as narration books for "The Tale of the Heike" assume an important role, and especially those based on Takano bon (Takano book) formally owned by Tatsuyuki TAKANO and currently by the Laboratory of Japanese, the University of Tokyo have been popularly distributed.

Among one hundred and several tens of denpon (existent books of transcription and published books) of "The Tale of the Heike," transcription and published books of the 'Kakuichi-bon Text' line as narration books for "The Tale of the Heike" assume an important role, and especially those based on Takano bon (Takano book) formally owned by Tatsuyuki TAKANO and currently by the Laboratory of Japanese, the University of Tokyo have been popularly distributed.

sen.j: 筑後国高良大社所蔵の重要文化財『平家物語』も覚一本である。
sen.e: The important cultural property "The Tale of the Heike" owned by the Kora Taisha Shrine in the Chikugo Province is also a Kakuichi-bon Text.
The important cultural property "The Tale of the Heike" owned by the Kora Taisha Shrine in the Chikugo Province is also a Kakuichi-bon Text.
The important cultural property "The Tale of the Heike" owned by the Kora Taisha Shrine in the Chikugo Province is also a Kakuichi-bon Text.

sen.j: さらに、足利氏出身であったことから室町幕府からも庇護を受け、中世から近世にかけて存在した男性盲人の自治的互助組織である当道座を開いた。
sen.e: Since he was from the Ashikaga Family, he was under the patronage of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and opened Todo-za, which was an autonomous mutual support group of visually impaired males and existed in the Medieval Period to the early-modern times.

Since he was from the Ashikaga Family, he was under the patronage of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and opened Todo-za, which was an autonomous mutual support group of visually impaired males that existed in the Medieval Period to the early-modern times.

Since he was from the Ashikaga Family, he was under the patronage of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and opened Todo-za, which was an autonomous mutual support group of visually impaired males that existed in the Medieval Period to the early-modern times.

sen.j: 当道座は、盲人の地位向上や生業の安定をはかるものであったが、生業に関して師匠から弟子へ技能を継承する教育機関としての役割も担い、本所は村上源氏に属する久我家であった。
sen.e: Todo-za was to advance visually impaired people and to secure their regular vocation, but also served as an educational institution for regular vocation to pass on skills from a master to an apprentice, and honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) was the Koga family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto Clan).

Todo-za was to advance visually impaired people and to secure their regular vocation, but also served as an educational institution for regular vocation to pass on skills from a master to an apprentice, and honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) was the Koga family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto Clan).

Todo-za was to advance visually impaired people and to secure their regular vocation, but also served as an educational institution for regular vocation to pass on skills from a master to an apprentice, and honjo (lord of the guild) was the Koga family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto Clan).
sen.cmt: ここでの「本所」は座の支配権者のことのため、定訳不明ですが訂正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代になると江戸幕府によって公認され、寺社奉行の管轄下にあった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Todo-za was authorized by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and was under the jurisdiction of jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).
In the Edo period, Todo-za was authorized by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and was under the jurisdiction of jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).
In the Edo period, Todo-za was authorized by the Edo bakufu, and was under the jurisdiction of jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines).

sen.j: 京都に惣検校が、一時は江戸にも関東惣検校が置かれた。
sen.e: So-kengyo (the chairman of the highest-rank officials of the guild for the blind) was placed in Kyoto, and Kanto so-kengyo was placed in Edo for a while.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 惣検校：関東惣検校との対比から、「so-kengyo」と記載し、用語集に載っていた訳語を括弧書きにしております。
sen.e: So-kengyo (the chairman of the highest-rank officials of the guild for the blind) was placed in Kyoto, and Kanto so-kengyo was placed in Edo for a while.

sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処原文も分けました。惣検校の説明、既出のため削除

sen.j: 惣検校が差配する役所は「当道職屋敷」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: The office governed by so-kengyo was called "Todo shokuyashiki."

sen.j: 職屋敷は、東洞院通近くの清聚庵にあり、覚一の屋敷があった場所とされている。
sen.e: Shokuyashiki was located at Seijuan near the Higashinotoin-dori street, and it is said that this is where the Kakuichi's residence was.

sen.j: 現在は小学校になっていて、校門の横に石碑がある。
sen.e: This is now an elementary school, and there is a stone monument beside a school gate.
